intro: Crocus versicolor var. lineatus, commonly known as the variegated crocus, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and parts of the Middle East. It belongs to the Iridaceae family and is characterized by its striking, colorful flowers that range from white to pink and yellow. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–20 cm and produces showy, spurred flowers in early spring. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, and it thrives in well-drained soil in full sun to partial shade. This variety is prized for its ornamental value and is often cultivated in gardens for its vibrant blooms.
